title: Please Help Me Find An Graphic Design Internship In NYC
content:
Hello,

My name is David Bailey, I will be a junior at Drexel University in Philadelphia this fall, majoring in Graphic Design. The reason for this post is regarding a two term co-op experience that I will have this coming fall/winter (approx. Sept. 20th to the middle of March). Drexel has counselors that will help us find co-ops next quarter but I'm starting my own search to hopefully land an interesting/good co-op job for the begining of the close approaching academic year. Drexel's Graphic Design program focuses mainly on the print side of the buisness (logo design, branding, page layout, poster/ad design, book cover design and product packaging).

I'm quite in love with my major and the work I do every day in class and for that reason would love to find an opportunity to spend my co-op at a buisness in NYC, a main hub of design these days. My work has been praised and won awards so I'm confident in my abilities, this is why I'm reaching for the best jobs out there. So far I've been in contact with RCA Records but I won't know if I have an interview for another couple weeks, which is cutting it dangerously close. I've attempted contacting a few smaller firms with no response yet. I'm about to just start calling the bigger names in the city (Poulin&Morris, Pentagram, etc.) to either get a yes or no about interns because I don't want to be stuck without a job. I'm quite aware of this being a Typography board but I'm spreading the word however I can. Please respond here if you have any sort of connections or work in the cit or even have your own buisness there! (or shoot me an email through the forums!) Regarding work I've done up to this point in school and on my own you can visit this link: [http://www.dsinelab.net/dave/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150413075159/http:/www.dsinelab.net/dave/index.html "http://www.dsinelab.net/dave/index.html") Best regards and thank you for taking time to read this. I'm aware this is only my second post here, but all the people I met at TypeCon were so friendly and I'm sure there are a plethora of designers here that might be able to help!

Attached are two photos of my latest work to entice some help!

David, you will have more luck after Labor Day. What happens in the business world is the budgets have been spent by Memorial Day (in general) and a lot of decision makers go on vacation during the summer months (kids out of school). A lot of agencies actually give staff members Fridays off during the summer. The approach I think you need to take is, research your potential targets and get an e-mail or something in print that arrives just after the Labor Day weekend. Don't get discourged and don't give up.

David, finding an internship in NYC can be as daunting as finding an empty cab on a rainy day. There are many interns from many local schools that get placed through their schools in the better firms. At Pentagram, for example, we have interns lined up for the next six months and we look for them much in advance and we usually do it through schools – also, interns are by "team" not as a whole, meaning that each partner is responsible for hiring their own interns, it is not an office wide initiative.

Other firms may be open to getting interns from independent initiatives like yours but it's usually easier when there is backing from a school program.

In the end, the best thing you can do is to call as many design firms as you can, get them to see you regardless of them having an opening or not (portfolio critiques can be extremely helpful and you will find that they will serve you better than awards or your work being praised). Try going through Workbook's directory, [http://www.workbook.com/phonebook/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150413075159/http:/www.workbook.com/phonebook/ "http://www.workbook.com/phonebook/") it's a great resource for all firms in Manhattan.

If you don't want to do web design, don't take an internship where you will be asked to do web stuff. You won't enjoy it and your employer will not get the best from you. If you like print, find a print internship, don't settle for anything you are not passionate about.

And remember that it's very competitive.

Oh, and yes, you will make lots of copies, mount many presentations and stay late working on making more copies and mounting many more presentations. Don't let that deter you, it's a very formative experience.

For what it's worth, email is much better than a phone call. It's much easier for me to follow a link in an email (or look at a PDF in an email) and make an assessment, than to screen someone over the phone and decide whether to have them come in. Unsolicited post cards and small portfolios are also great. The days of the giant book drop off are gone, and for good reason.

Best of luck.

\> _For what it’s worth, email is much better than a phone call._

Yes, e-mail is usually a good way to contact principals and creative directors – by "call" I meant "contact somehow". I would only recommend you call first (hopefully you'll get a nice receptionist willing to divulge the information) to find out who to send an e-mail to. It's better than sending an e-mail to [info@companyx.com](mailto:info@companyx.com) and addressing it "To whom it may concern". Once you send the e-mail, tell them you WILL call them in x days to follow up, and then call them.

\> email is much better than a phone call.

Hear, hear.

To me, phone calls are most useful if you're hiding something.

I'm going to talk to one of my professors who runs a Professional Practice class before I go on the interview so that I'm 100% prepared but I'd appreciate any tips you guys have! I've never really gone on one before, but these are my thoughts:

1. Have questions to ask about what the job/internship will entail.  
2. Research/know information about the respective company and what they do.  
3. More questions about the actual company.  
4. Dress appropriately, I don't own a suit or anything but have heard that interviews for design jobs aren't as formal as some other jobs in how you should dress. I figure some nice dressy pants and a matching collared shirt with some decent shoes, not sneakers!  
5. Be confident and friendly.  
6. Send a thank you note for the interview after the fact.

What else? :D

-Dave
Don't forget to shake their hand and look them in the eye as you talk.

Hi all, I didn't want to bump this quite yet but seeing as how you're interested! I had my interview at RCA Records in Times Square on Thursday and it went EXTREMELY well! They hadn't interviewed anyone else and really liked my work. They'll let me know this week if I got it! It was a surprisingly small office for such a large company. I interviewed with the Creative and Video Manager then there are 2 ADs, 2 Freelance Designers and interns. The woman who I interviewed with was really laid back and easy to talk to. She asked how many days I wanted to work and told me what I'd be doing for work, 90% design and 10% administrative but that they wouldn't make me do anything that they wouldn't do. No office bitch work ;) I asked questions about what went on in the office, who handled certain tasks, how many jobs they had going at once and about the record label in general. I was told that they would give me as much work as I could handle so that's exciting. If this fails for some odd reason I'll be pursuing your help more in the next week or so!

-Dave
